Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2012 02:12PM - edited Dec 27, 2012 02:13PM by doubleAA For some reason, whenever I have to talk to someone (checkout operator at supermarket, taxi driver, whoever) I have an almost overwhelming desire to burst into tears and tell them "I've just been diagnosed with breast cancer". Why the whole world needs to be privy to my problems I'm not too sure, but that's the way I'm feeling right now.  I am just past my one year anniversary and when I read this I wanted you to Know I was like this too. I found it easier and cathartic to tell the Clinique salesclerk why I was looking for a new lipstick then to tell a friend or loved one. Each time I told someone it made it more commonplace until one day I was able to say I have breast cancer without welling up or crying. It gets easier as treatment plans get set in place and once you start on your course of treatment. I didn't take anything to get me through nor was it offered. With chemo I was prescribed Ativan which was only taken 1x a day at night and I took it reluctantly at first. It helped me sleep after taking the steroids and I guess calmed me down as well. My doc even said it had an antinausea benefit. Do what you need to do and what is right for you. That's the number one rule I learned from this experience. Good luck to you.

Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2012 09:22PM doubleAA wrote: I had my surgeries at Sloane and right before I had my exchange they changed their policy about tamoxifen and required me to be off it for 14 days before. Because of the change I was only off for 10 days. I discussed with my MO (not a Sloane MO) and he said it was fine. The risk of being on is blood clots. My MO said that the benefits of Tamoxifen stays in your body for 30 days. He also told me not to "freak" if I forgot to take a dose every now and then because it stays in the body for 30 days. Hope this helps you.

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2012 05:41AM doubleAA wrote: Bessie's list is excellent. I had a UMX just over a year ago with reconstruction. I remember going back and forth on my decision. A few things my breast surgeon said that ultimately helped me make my decision was 1) my breast surgeon said that if she removed the breast without cancer that she would want to take a lymph node for testing on the " non" cancerous side. 2) that I needed to be 100% secure in my decision to remove my "healthy" breast because there is no going back, but if I was not 100% sure that if is something that could always be done at a later date ( not that I would have wanted more surgery) 3) that by removing the healthy breast, I actually opened myself up to complications, there could be complications with the tissue expanders, lymphodema etc The decision is personal and you've got to really think about what you want. I had a good breast surgeon and plastic surgeon. Dressed my girls look good. Naked I've got one natural breast and one foob, but it doesn't bother me in the least. As I said, I am a little moe than a year out from my UMX and six months from my reconstruction. I was very lucky and had minimal side effects. I did have some cording after surgery that needed pt to get my range of motion back. The issues that bother me a year out are, numbness under my arm from the lymh node removal (have been told this can take two years to go away or it may never) lack of strength on my surgical side, and the fear of lymphodema. So yes with those three things being said and now that I have some hindsight I am glad I only did a UMX. I do have some fear of getting breast cancer in my natural breast but for now, I can live with that.

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2012 04:15PM doubleAA wrote: My children were 14 and 16 when I had my surgery this past Dec and we were dealing with the fact that I had breast cancer as well. At that age they are very aware and once we had our gameplan, we told them everything - no holding back - they asked whatever questions they wanted and we answered.  I talked openly but in moderation about my fear, and that I knew this was a blip in the road and all was going to be good.  I found that as long as I didn't dwell in the dark places around my kids they were great.  My younger one (the girl) was definately more attached during the days leading up to surgery and after.  I also contacted the guidance counselors at school and let them know what was going on so that they could have the additional support if need be at school.  I told them the date of the surgery and when I was expected to be home so they could keep a closer watch on them that day.  Hope this helps. Good luck with everything.

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2012 09:20AM doubleAA wrote: What will I feel?  You will feel like you. I woke up and knew I had surgery and saw my husband and realized I'm still me. I was another one of the odd ones I guess not much pain just some discomfort. Soreness like after the hardest weight workout you ever did. But even if you have more than this there are pain meds to help. You don't mention if you are having reconstruction. I had a unilateral on the right side. When you come out of surgery you already have a surgical bra on. I was not ready to "look" right away. My breast surgeon helped me with that the next morning when I saw her. I am small busted and had a TE placed so I had a breast mound. She opened the surgical bra just slightly at first and showed me that I still had for lack of a better word cleavage (cause when you're a 34a there really is not much). Then she opened it a drop more and I was able to see my skin. I think after looking at too many mastecomy pictures on the web I forgot it would still be me. I saw my freckle that I have on my right boob and was like cool. I was so much more comfortable. I could not see the scar from looking down. It did take me a few days to look head on and at that point it was totally fine. The scar at first is very red. But this gets better. Do your range of motion exercises. You won't want to but you will want full mobility back and this is how you get it. Any problems you are having with them make sure to convey to your surgeon. I wish you the best of everything!
